values:
Once I fell in love with a girl at the playground; it happened only 
Once when I was a mere four years old.
Once when innocence was bliss and
Once when my mind could not leave her.
Once I fell in love, I was happy only to realize 
Once that she would be forever gone the next day.
Once I realized that my heart was broken then 
Once I will never be the same.
Once I was fooled into thinking that for 
Once I had found the girl of my dreams, yet
Once I realized she was gone forever, I knew at
Once that it was not meant to be.
Once the pain had subsided, it never
Once left my memory and 
Once and for all time will I be haunted by 
Once when my dear love left me.

Looking at the prompt and reading through the various responses, I find it very reassuring that I can relate to many of them.  It is nice to be able to read through other honors' students responses and know that I am not alone in the pressure felt from school and from other outside influences.  as mentioned already by many, the transition to college life has been a difficult one, and I know in the long run it will be another one of those difficult transitional phases on the path toward growth.  Looking back, i dont know if i can point my finger to any specific moment that has caused a paradigm shift in my life, yet I know i have been through many difficult transitional phases that have greatly influenced my life for the better.  I went to a small Christian school for 10yrs in small town Roswell, New Mexico. I had the same friends and classmates since kindergarten, and I thought I would eventually end up graduating from high school there as valedictorian of my class and all that good stuff.  However, things can change rather quickly. In a crazy turn of events, the school i had gone to all my life ended up splitting due to unrenconcilable differences.  A new Christian school was formed down the street, and I ended up going to high school there my sophomore year.  However, again things can change rather quickly.  At the end of my sophomore year, my family decided to move to Phoenix, Arizona, because we thought it would be a better situation for us. So after all this, i ended up going to to my third high school - a large public school after 10yrs. of going to the same small Christian school for almost all my life.  This period in my life was a very difficult transitional phase that i really learned a lot from.  It was a really humbling experience going from the top of my class in a school where i had known everyone all my life to a new environment where i didnt know anyone and was no longer "the smart kid."  It was an experience that has really given my a new perspective in life, and in some sense, it really helped prepare me for the next state of transitiion - college.

 In retrospect, it seems, for the most part, that my life has been a gradual growing process of taking two steps forward and one step back, so to speak.  In the process, I have gone through many difficult times that have shaped my perspective of life.  It seems that after these moments of epiphany we go through, we are on fire and are passionate for a while only to reach a plateau in life in which we must take one step back, reevaluate life, and take steps to further growth.  At this point in my life, i really find myself reevaluating life and finding direction during these difficult times.  Sometimes it seems like i cant cope and want to give up, but what keeps me going is my faith in God and my hope that no matter what happens all things will work out for the best.  If there is any moment in my life that i can point to as being a paradigm shift in my life, it would have to be the moment i dedicated my life to God as a Christian.  It has been that decision that has allowed me to shift my perspective and have hope during difficult times.  Along the way, I have grown a lot, but the defining moment in my life has been that decision to follow God.  I know that I am not a perfect person and am often shortsighted, but it is in knowing God's love for me that keeps me coming back on track after going astray and has allowed me to focus not on my inadequacies but in knowing that He is in control of my life.  It is in knowing this that i can be at peace with myself, "not afraid to die." It has truly given me the feeling of freedom "in fact" while "remain[ing] one in form."

In reading the passage by barthes,i began to relate his idea of "straining toward the essence" to our good friend Plato and his Theory of Forms.  Plato talks about how there are two realms - the material realm and the realm of forms.  The material realm is the physical world we live in which everything we see is a mere shadow or copy of the perfect world or the realm of forms.  For example, we see a dog or chair in the material world, and these items are merely duplicates of the perfect or "ideal" dog or chair in the realm of forms.  This same principle works with ideas as well which is why i tried to relate it to barthe's longing to search for "the essence."  In terms of Plato's explanation, it seems as if barthe will never be able to truly find his mother's essense in a photograph because it is only a tangible idea that represents an even higher form.  

We cannot begin to associate one's essence in a tangible form such as a picture.  In one's own thinking, he cannot even begin to grasp such a subjective idea. This is why barthe states that "i dream about her, i do not dream her."  Barthe only sees a representation of his mother and will never be able to grasp the idea of her essence in a tangible sense.  The example often used to describe Plato's Theory of Forms is the one of the sculptor.  A sculptor has an idea that he wishes to reproduce in the form of a statue.  He impresses his idea in the form of a sculputre, yet his sculpture only represents his idea. It can never be or affect the actual idea itself because the idea is immutable - it resides in a higher form.   

Similarly, I see barthe's photographs of his mother as serving this same idea.  He longs to find the true "essence" of her mother, yet he will never be able to find it in this world because of the inherent flawed nature of the physical world.  Yet, I still think that barthe's search for "the essence" is stil important and worthwile.  Plato stated that learning is a process in which we gain more understanding through reasoning and trying to understand the ideas of the higher realm.  In terms of these ideas it seems as if the reason we live is to find meaning or "the essence" and ultimately give meaning to life in finding these answers.  Therefore, perhaps in searching for "the essence" in simple things such as that of a photograph, one can begin to gain more understanding of what "the essence" really is and in this process strive to fulfill a greater good.
